title: How to Cut Jicama

steps.headline: Clean the jicama.
steps.description: Run the jicama under a stream of cold water for a minute to rinse it. Use a paper towel to thoroughly rub the vegetable. Dry the jicama.

steps.headline: Slice of the top and bottom of the jicama.
steps.description: Set out a clean cutting board. Gently cut off a slice from the top and bottom of the jicama. Rest the vegetable on the broader end, sitting up.

steps.headline: Remove the skin with a sharp knife.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to peel the jicama, as the tough skin will be difficult for an ordinary vegetable peeler to handle. Working from the top to bottom, slide your knife under the surface of the jicama to remove the skin. Continue around the entire surface of the vegetable until all of the skin is removed. You can use a vegetable peeler to run over the skinned jicama and remove any tiny spots of skin that remain.

steps.headline: Cut the jicama into round, flat pieces.
steps.description: Cut a piece off the bottom of your jicama to make sure that it has a large, flat surface to lie flat on while you cut it. Start from the side and cut large, round pieces of jicama. Each slice should be about a quarter of an inch (approximately 0.7 cm) thick.

steps.headline: Turn the jicama over halfway through to keep cutting.
steps.description: Once you have cut halfway through the jicawa, turn it over to rest on its largest, flattest surface. Continue to cut large pieces, about a quarter of an inch (approximately 0.7 cm) thick. Gather the large jicawa pieces once you are done.

steps.headline: Cut the jicama into long, fry-shaped sticks.
steps.description: Carefully brace pieces of jicama with the opposite hand and use your knife to cut the jicama into long sticks. Aim for the pieces to be a quarter of an inch (approximately 0.7 cm) thick all around. Serve these sticks raw, or coat them in oil and bake them in the oven to make jicama "fries."

steps.headline: Use a mandoline to cut the jicama into matchsticks.
steps.description: Cut your peeled jicama into quarters or halves. Use a mandoline to cut very thin pieces (approximately an eighth of an inch, or about 0.3 cm, thick) of the vegetable. Using a sharp knife, cut these pieces into matchsticks of equal width. You  can also use a mandoline to simply cut thin, wide pieces of jicama.

steps.headline: Dice jicama.
steps.description: Once you have cut your jicama into long sticks (either thicker, fry-shaped pieces or small matchsticks) dicing them is easy. Use your knife to cut across the sticks of jicama, gently bracing them with your other hand. Cut uniform pieces that can be used to make salsa or other treats.

steps.headline: Shred jicama.
steps.description: Shredded jicama can be a great addition to coleslaw and salads. Peel and cut a jicama into quarters with a sharp knife. Run each quarter over a box grater to shred it. Dab the shredded jicama to remove excess moisture before adding it to your recipe to keep it from clumping together.

text: Preparing Jicama Clean the jicama. Run the jicama under a stream of cold water for a minute to rinse it. Use a paper towel to thoroughly rub the vegetable. Dry the jicama. Slice of the top and bottom of the jicama. Set out a clean cutting board. Gently cut off a slice from the top and bottom of the jicama. Rest the vegetable on the broader end, sitting up. Remove the skin with a sharp knife. Use a sharp knife to peel the jicama, as the tough skin will be difficult for an ordinary vegetable peeler to handle. Working from the top to bottom, slide your knife under the surface of the jicama to remove the skin. Continue around the entire surface of the vegetable until all of the skin is removed. You can use a vegetable peeler to run over the skinned jicama and remove any tiny spots of skin that remain. Cutting Jicama Cut the jicama into round, flat pieces. Cut a piece off the bottom of your jicama to make sure that it has a large, flat surface to lie flat on while you cut it. Start from the side and cut large, round pieces of jicama. Each slice should be about a quarter of an inch (approximately 0.7 cm) thick. Turn the jicama over halfway through to keep cutting. Once you have cut halfway through the jicawa, turn it over to rest on its largest, flattest surface. Continue to cut large pieces, about a quarter of an inch (approximately 0.7 cm) thick. Gather the large jicawa pieces once you are done. Cut the jicama into long, fry-shaped sticks. Carefully brace pieces of jicama with the opposite hand and use your knife to cut the jicama into long sticks. Aim for the pieces to be a quarter of an inch (approximately 0.7 cm) thick all around. Serve these sticks raw, or coat them in oil and bake them in the oven to make jicama "fries." Use a mandoline to cut the jicama into matchsticks. Cut your peeled jicama into quarters or halves. Use a mandoline to cut very thin pieces (approximately an eighth of an inch, or about 0.3 cm, thick) of the vegetable. Using a sharp knife, cut these pieces into matchsticks of equal width. You  can also use a mandoline to simply cut thin, wide pieces of jicama. Dice jicama. Once you have cut your jicama into long sticks (either thicker, fry-shaped pieces or small matchsticks) dicing them is easy. Use your knife to cut across the sticks of jicama, gently bracing them with your other hand. Cut uniform pieces that can be used to make salsa or other treats. Shred jicama. Shredded jicama can be a great addition to coleslaw and salads. Peel and cut a jicama into quarters with a sharp knife. Run each quarter over a box grater to shred it. Dab the shredded jicama to remove excess moisture before adding it to your recipe to keep it from clumping together.
